unnormalised: Planning a trip within India? Booking accommodation can be confusing with all the different address formats. Let's break it down so you can avoid those "address not found" errors. Understanding addresses here goes beyond just memorizing a format; it’s about grasping the cultural nuances.
normalised: Planning a trip within India? Booking accommodation can be confusing with all the different address formats. Let's break it down so you can avoid those "address not found" errors. Understanding addresses here goes beyond just memorizing a format; it's about grasping the cultural nuances.

unnormalised: First, realize that Indian addresses often start with the most specific information and gradually broaden. A typical residential address might look like this: "Flat No. 201, Block C, Rose Apartments, M.G. Road, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560001." Notice the flow from the flat number to the postal code.
normalised: First, realize that Indian addresses often start with the most specific information and gradually broaden. A typical residential address might look like this: "Flat Number two hundred and one, Block C, Rose Apartments, M-G Road, Bangalore, Karnataka, five hundred and sixty thousand and one." Notice the flow from the flat number to the postal code.

unnormalised: For hotel bookings, the format can be a bit trickier. You might see addresses like "Hotel Grand Plaza, 19/2, Nehru Place, New Delhi, 110019" or "Taj Mahal Palace, Apollo Bunder, Colaba, Mumbai, Maharashtra, 400001." Note the use of the building name (Hotel Grand Plaza, Taj Mahal Palace) as the primary identifier. Always double-check the pin code! 110019 for Nehru Place and 400001 for Colaba are easily confused, and the difference will land your courier in the wrong place.
normalised: For hotel bookings, the format can be a bit trickier. You might see addresses like "Hotel Grand Plaza, nineteen divided by two, Nehru Place, New Delhi, one hundred and ten thousand and nineteen" or "Taj Mahal Palace, Apollo Bunder, Colaba, Mumbai, Maharashtra, four hundred thousand and one." Note the use of the building name (Hotel Grand Plaza, Taj Mahal Palace) as the primary identifier. Always double-check the P-I-N code! One hundred and ten thousand and nineteen for Nehru Place and four hundred thousand and one for Colaba are easily confused, and the difference will land your courier in the wrong place.

unnormalised: Also, many Indian addresses use landmarks as points of reference. You could find something like "Near City Centre Mall, D.N. Road, Kolkata, 700064" or "Opposite SBI Bank, Main Road, Chennai, Tamil Nadu, 600002." These landmarks are invaluable for auto-rickshaw drivers and delivery personnel alike. Don't underestimate their importance! If a GPS signal is lost, "opposite SBI Bank" can save the day.

These landmarks are invaluable for auto-rickshaw drivers and delivery personnel alike. Don't underestimate their importance! If a G-P-S signal is lost, "opposite S-B-I Bank" can save the day.

unnormalised: Online booking portals sometimes have address fields that don’t quite match the Indian format. In these cases, try to break down the address into smaller parts. For example, if there's a "Street Address 1" and "Street Address 2" field, you could put "Flat No. 201, Block C" in the first and "Rose Apartments, M.G. Road" in the second.

For example, if there's a "Street Address one" and "Street Address two" field, you could put "Flat Number two hundred and one, Block C" in the first and "Rose Apartments, M-G Road" in the second.

unnormalised: Remember the importance of abbreviations. "M.G. Road" stands for Mahatma Gandhi Road. You'll also see "Rd" for Road, "St" for Street, "Colony" abbreviated as "Col", and "Society" as "Soc." Knowing these abbreviations will help you decipher addresses quickly. "H.No 1234" means House Number 1234.

"House Number one thousand two hundred and thirty four" means House Number one thousand two hundred and thirty four.

unnormalised: Don't forget the PIN code (Postal Index Number), a six-digit code that's essential for mail delivery. Always include it in your address, even if it's not explicitly asked for. It significantly speeds up the delivery process. In the addresses mentioned before, 560001 (Bangalore), 110019 (New Delhi), 400001 (Mumbai), 700064 (Kolkata), and 600002 (Chennai) are all vital parts.

unnormalised: If you're booking accommodation through a local travel agent, confirm the address details with them. Agents in India, especially those in smaller cities, may use slightly different address conventions compared to international online portals.

unnormalised: Lastly, be patient. Indian addresses can be complex and sometimes inconsistent. Double-check all details, use landmarks where possible, and don't hesitate to call the hotel or property directly to confirm the address if you're unsure. A little extra effort upfront can save you a lot of headaches later.
